paper_abstract: Multi-gate transistors enable the pace of Moore's Law for another decade. In its 22 nm technology node Intel switched to multi-gate transistors called TriGate, whereas IBM, TSMC, Samsung and others will do so in their 20 nm and 14 nm nodes with multi-gate transistors called FinFET. Several recent publications studied the drawing of multi-gate transistors layout. Designing new VLSI cell libraries and blocks requires massive re-drawing of layout. Hard-IP reuse is an alternative method taking advantage of existing source layout by automatically mapping it into new target technology, which was used in Intel's Tick-Tock marketing strategy for several product generations. This paper presents a cell-level hard-IP reuse algorithm, converting planar transistors to multi-gate ones. We show an automatic, robust transformation of bulk diffusion polygons into fins, while addressing the key requirements of cell libraries, as maximizing performance and interface compatibility across a variety of driving strength. We present a layout conversion flow comprising time-efficient geometric manipulations and discrete optimization algorithms, while generating manually drawn layout quality. Those can easily be used in composing larger functional blocks. (C) 2013 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
paper_title: Planar CMOS to multi-gate layout conversion for maximal fin utilization
